newsitem.title: UK: NatWest Markets loses long-serving banker.
newsitem.headline: NatWest Markets loses long-serving banker.

text.p: NatWest Markets, the investment banking arm of Britain's NatWest Bank, confirmed on Thursday it had lost a senior member of its loan syndication division to Dutch financial giant ABN AMRO Holding NV.

A NatWest Markets spokeswoman told Reuters that Gary Griffiths, a director of syndications, had resigned from the firm on Wednesday. Banking sources said he had been hired as head of loan syndication at ABN AMRO in London.
ABN AMRO was not immediately available for comment on the appointment.

Griffiths' departure was widely discussed in the loan market on Thursday because of his long-standing with NatWest, where they said he had been for 25 years. Griffiths reported to Grant Johnson, head of loan syndication at NatWest Markets.
Most recently he focused on syndicating debt facilities backing project financing, market sources said.
The bank has been the subject of intense speculation following the resignation on Monday of NatWest Markets' chief executive Martin Owen and the announcement of a major strategy overhaul.
NatWest Group chief executive Derek Wanless, who is also acting head of the investment bank until Owen's replacement is found, said on Monday the firm would reassess its lending.
But NatWest Markets would not withdraw from the loan market altogether, although it would review some "low-yielding, big ticket lending".
"There is still a role for that if it is part of an overall relationship with a client which is profitable, but in isolation its a very low-yielding business," he told Reuters.
